intro.description: You have now provided background data to SATC, now you can ask it to generate a solution.

item.title: Calculate the solution
item.description:
It's quite easy really, just click on Calculate Solution. Within a second or so you will see a new track appear on the plot (though you may need to zoom out a little).
The track will be the same color as you specified for the bearing data in the Bearing Import Wizard.
By default, SATC is in Low precision. This instructs SATC to use fairly relaxed constraints, and come up with an answer within a few seconds. In this scenario we have quite sparse bearing data, and the ownship maneouvres mean that there aren't very many candidate solutions.
At the time of writing (April 2014), a solution of 9.0kts on 269 degrees is returned. If you wish, you can try using a high precision. I don't think you will get a better solution, but you will notice that the Performance graph (at the bottom of the (Maintain Contributions view) growing more slowly as SATC homes in on a particular solution. You will see that the x-axis (on the bottom) shows more cycles have been run through, and that each one moves more slowly.

item.title: Marking your own homework
item.description:
The data we're using here is from a simulation tool. That means we also have the target track. So, try dragging in L1_SubjectTrack.rep and comparing the SATC solution with the truth track.
You will see that SATC is quite close to the truth, with a greater error to the West, near the start. This is because of the low bearing rate near the start - both tracks appear to be on a roughly parallel course.
